there's a good chance you've never heard
of this country before as it gets to
70,000 foreign visitors a year so let me
introduce you to one of the most
interesting humble and innovative
countries in the world the kingdom of
Bhutan is about the size of Maryland
with the population of Alaska but tucked
away deep in the Himalayan mountains
between the world's two most populous
countries India and China but unlike its
chaotic neighbours life in Bhutan is
quiet and charming with majestic
Buddhist temples surrounded by rolling
green hills and fresh rivers it honestly
feels like another planet of pure magic
Bhutan is the last standing Buddhist
kingdom on earth they've never been
colonized by a foreign power
so life today is pretty much the same as
it's been for thousands of years the
official language of Bhutan is Hong Kong
and it sounds like this cotton sheet
thank you same catchment
now give me drew ela in terms of
economics Bhutan is thriving its economy
is projected to grow by 7.1 percent in
2018 the second fastest growth rate in
the world behind India we are not
walking by the Buddha Jordan ma it costs
200 million US dollars to construct but
here in Bhutan they don't use GDP to
measure their country's prosperity they
use GNH Gross National Happiness yes
it's a real thing Bhutan is consistently
ranked as the happiest country in Asia
and it's obvious when you see their
smiles more on their happiness in
another video what I love most about
Bhutan is that they make a strong effort
to preserve their culture their nature
and their rituals it's a month they want
to remain isolated from our
ever-changing globalized world and
they're very slow to adapt to a
modernized life traditional up until
one Putin had no roads no cars and no
electricity they didn't have TV or
Internet until 1999 and even today there
are no traffic lights in the country
even in the capital of timbu the
government limits tourism by charging a
hefty fee of 250 dollars per person per
day and it's mandatory for all visitors
to have a guide kind of like North Korea
but if you ask me it's a hundred percent
worth the price to witness something
this special
let's talk nature cuz I just look at
this place take a fantasy world you know
Wonderland Bhutan is 72% forested the
rest of the country is covered with
green mountains deep valleys wildlife
sanctuaries and nature reserves the air
is so fresh the views are so stunning
and you will not find a single piece of
trash where it shouldn't be
Bouton's beautiful nature remains
untouched as the country is a global
leader in sustainability and protecting
their environment it's the world's only
carbon negative country meaning it
absorbs more co2 than it gives out it's
also the world's only country whose
largest export is renewable energy
despite being in Bhutan for just 48
hours so far I am overjoyed by what I've
seen and it has led me to ponder the
question what has the Western world done
wrong this is how life is supposed to be
lived
I'm drew pinsky and if you like my
